newsitem.title: USA: Countdown runs smoothly for shuttle launch.
newsitem.headline: Countdown runs smoothly for shuttle launch.

text.p: The countdown was proceeding smoothly for Thursday's planned blastoff of the space shuttle Columbia on a 16-day science mission, NASA officials said on Tuesday.

Only two minor problems had cropped up since the shuttle's three-day countdown began on Monday. A gas sensor in the shuttle's fuselage had failed and one of the cockpit displays was flickering occasionally. Neither should delay the launch, NASA test director Doug Lyons said.
Columbia, which made the first shuttle flight in 1981, was scheduled for a rare afternoon liftoff from Florida's Kennedy Space Centre at 2:01 p.m. EST (1901 GMT) on Thursday.
Meteorologists were confidently predicting fair weather for the shuttle's 2-1/2 hour launch window. They gave the shuttle an 80 percent chance of blasting off on time.
Columbia's crew of seven were to operate a microgravity laboratory around the clock, performing combustion research and materials processing.
